choices.text: Administer antipyretics and treat wheeze symptomatically
Initiate daily antiepileptic therapy with valproate

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency department after an episode of generalised jerky movements with up-rolling of eyes, lasting about 2 minutes. The mother reports the child had a fever (101.2°F) before the episode, ongoing for the past day. There is no history of prior seizures or developmental delay. On examination, the child is now alert and playful, and wheeze is noted on chest auscultation. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation is consistent with a simple febrile seizure triggered by an underlying respiratory infection.
  • The seizure was generalised, lasted less than 2 minutes, and there is no history of prior seizures, focal features, or postictal complications.
  • The child is now alert and neurologically normal, fulfilling all criteria for a simple febrile seizure.
  • In such cases, no antiepileptic therapy or neuroimaging is required. (Option A, B, C ruled out)
  • Since the seizure is not ongoing on presentation, the appropriate management involves symptomatic and supportive care, specifically:
    • Temperature control with antipyretics
    • Treatment of the underlying respiratory illness
    • Parental reassurance and education

Treatment of active febrile seizure:

  • Rectal benzodiazepine (such as diazepam) is used to terminate the seizure, while antipyretics are administered to improve the child's comfort by controlling the fever.
  • If the seizure lasts for longer than 5 minutes, acute treatment with lorazepam, midazolam, or diazepam is needed.

Prophylaxis:

  • Indications:
    • Any risk factor for febrile seizure Or
    • > 3 febrile seizures in 6 months Or
    • > 4 febrile seizures in 1 year.
  • Intermittent prophylaxis during febrile illnesses can be given using oral diazepam or oral clonazepam for 3-5 days, and may be continued as needed until the child reaches 5 years of age. (Option A ruled out)
  • Such therapies help reduce, but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.

Explanation of other options:

Consider EEG and imaging (Option B): A CT or MRI is not recommended in evaluating the child after a first simple febrile seizure. The workup of children with complex febrile seizures needs to be individualised. This can include an EEG and neuroimaging, particularly if the child is neurologically abnormal.

Initiate daily antiepileptic therapy with valproate (Option D): Continuous therapy with the antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) phenobarbital or valproic acid, were occasionally used to prevent febrile seizures. However, in the vast majority of cases, use of continuous therapy is not justified because of the risk of side effects and lack of demonstrated long-­ term benefits, even if the recurrence rate of febrile seizures is expected to be decreased by these drugs. Chronic antiepileptic therapy may be considered for children with a high risk for later epilepsy. The possibility of future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.

Treatment algorithm for febrile seizures:

choices.text: LP is performed at or above L1-L2 to ensure maximum cerebrospinal fluid yield
LP is indicated in all cases of meningitis
LP is safe to perform in a hemodynamically unstable child if no signs of raised ICP are seen
CSF samples collected during LP are routinely sent for cell count, protein, glucose, Gram stain, and culture

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding lumbar puncture is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

About 1 mL of CSF is collected in sterile tubes for routine culture, glucose and protein determination and cell count. Additional samples are collected as indicated.

Site of LP in children:

  • In children, the spinal cord ends at approximately the level of the L1 and L2 vertebral bodies. Caudal to L2, only the filum terminale is present.
  • The ideal site for lumbar puncture is the interspinous space between L3-L4 or L4-L5, below the termination of the conus medullaris at L1. (Option A ruled out)
  • The physician identifies the appropriate interspace by drawing an imaginary line from the iliac crest downward perpendicular to the vertebral column.

Indications for LP:

  • Diagnosis of meningitis, encephalitis and idiopathic intracranial hypertension
  • Assessing subarchinoid hemorrhage
  • Demyelinating, degenerative, and collagen vascular diseases
  • Intracranial neoplasms.
  • Intrathecal drug administration

Contraindication of LP:

  • CNS lesion or spinal mass leading to increased intracranial pressure
  • Symptoms and signs of impending cerebral herniation in a child with probable meningitis (Option B ruled out)
  • Critical illness, hemodynamic instability (Option C ruled out)
  • Skin infection at the site of the lumbar puncture
  • Thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of <20 × 109/L.

questions.text: A 15-month-old child is brought to the ER after a seizure episode. The parents report a history of fever for 1 day. Upon examination, the child is febrile, with a normal neurological examination. Which of the following is not considered a major risk factor for recurrence of febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Complex febrile seizure is a minor risk factor, not a major factor for recurrence of febrile seizures.

  • Febrile seizures are seizures that occur between the ages of 6 and 60 months of life (peak 12-­ 18 months old) with a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher, that is not the result of CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance, and that occur in the absence of a history of prior afebrile seizures.
  • A simple febrile seizure is a primary generalised, usually tonic-­ clonic, attack associated with fever, lasting for a maximum of 15 minutes, and not recurrent within a 24-­ hour period.
  • A complex febrile seizure is more prolonged (>15 minutes), and/or is focal, and/or recurs within 24 hours.
  • Febrile status epilepticus is a febrile seizure lasting longer than 30 minutes.

Risk factors for recurrence of febrile seizures.

Major:

  • Age < 1 year
  • Duration of fever < 24 hr
  • Fever 38-39°C (100.4 - 102°F)

Minor:

  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Low serum sodium at the time of presentation

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with complaints of dropping objects from her hands, which are more frequent in the early morning. There is no history of loss of consciousness. Her cousin was recently diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG showed findings consistent with epileptic seizures. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Morning myoclonic jerks causing dropping objects without loss of consciousness, positive family history, and EEG showing generalised epileptiform discharges are classic for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy:

  • Also known asJanz Syndrome
  • Typically presents between 12 and 18 years and can persist into adulthood.
  • It is more common in females and often has a strong positive family history.
  • Several genes, including CACNB and GABRA1, have been implicated.

Morphology:

  • The hallmark feature is myoclonic jerks, seen in 100% of patients.
  • Most prominent in the morning while awake.
  • Precipitated by:
    • Awaking from sleep
    • Lack of sleep-in preceding night
  • Patients frequently report dropping objects from their hands.
  • Other seizure types may include generalised tonic-clonic seizures (50-90%) and absence seizures (25%).
  • Cognitive function is typically normal, with no mental retardation.

EEG findings and treatment:

  • EEG characteristically shows 4-6 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges.
  • The drug of choice is valproate, with lamotrigine or levetiracetam as effective second-line options.

Explanation of other options:

Atypical absence seizures (Option A): Absence seizures are generalised seizures consisting of staring, unresponsiveness, and eye flutter lasting usually for a few seconds. Atypical absences are associated with 1-­ to 2-­ Hz spike-and-slow-­ wave discharges and with head atonia and myoclonus during the seizures. They occur in Lennox-­ Gastaut syndrome.

Choreo-athetoid epilepsy (Option B): Childhood epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes, also called benign Rolandic epilepsy, typically presents between 5 and 10 years of age. Seizures typically arise during sleep or upon awakening and are focal motor, involving the face and arm, and may present with perioral twitching or tingling, drooling, guttural vocalisations, and brief speech or swallowing impairment. EEG shows independent bilateral centrotemporal sharp waves, with an otherwise normal background.

Progressive myoclonic epilepsy (Option C): Progressive myoclonic epilepsy is characterised by progressive worsening myoclonic along with dementia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of aseptic meningitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common causes of aseptic meningitis are viruses, especially enteroviruses like coxackievirus and echovirus.

  • Aseptic meningitis is the inflammation of the brain meninges caused by various factors, leading to sterile CSF cultures.
  • The most frequent cause is enteroviruses, though other viruses such as HSV, the mumps virus, JE virus, adenovirus, etc, are also implicated.

Explanation of other options:

Mumps virus (Option B): Before the introduction of the MMR vaccine, mumps was the most common cause of aseptic meningitis. In such cases, meningitis is often accompanied by parotitis and may also be associated with orchitis or oophoritis.

Herpes simplex virus (Option C): HSV is also a cause of aseptic meningitis, but is the most common cause of recurrent aseptic meningitis (Mollaret meningitis).

Cryptococcus neofromans (Option D): Cryptococcus is a fungal pathogen that primarily causes opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals. It is often associated with chronic meningitis. Diagnosis is made by India ink preparation, cryptococcal antigen test, or CSF culture.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the ER with a generalised tonic-clonic seizure lasting more than 45 minutes. Which of the following represents the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child is in status epilepticus, and management involves benzodiazepines such as lorazepam as first-line therapy, followed by the use of antiepileptic drugs like phenytoin, valproate, or levetiracetam if seizures persist.

Status epilepticus:

  • Refers to continuous convulsive activity lasting 5 min or longer (or)
  • Multiple generalised convulsions without gain of consciousness, lasting 5 min or longer
  • If activity > 30 min, serious neuro sequelae may develop.
  • Status epilepticus (SE) is a medical emergency that should be anticipated in any patient who presents with an acute seizure.
  • The most common cause of status epilepticus is a febrile seizure (febrile status epilepticus ~ 40% cases of status epilepticus).

Management guidelines:

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, vomiting, headache and intolerance to light. On examination,n he has neck stiffness, and a lumbar puncture was performed. CSF findings are as follows: 150 cells/mm3, protein 100 mg% and glucose of 75 mg%. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features and CSF findings - raised cells, raised protein in CSF with normal CSF glucose are suggestive of aseptic meningitis (viral meningitis).

  • Aseptic meningitis is the inflammation of the brain meninges caused by various factors, leading to sterile CSF cultures.
  • The most frequent cause is enteroviruses, though other viruses such as HSV, the mumps virus, JE virus, adenovirus, etc, are also implicated.
  • CSF findings include:
    • Pleocytosis (generally <500 but occasionally as high as 1,000-­ 8,000 WBCs/μL; often predominantly polymorphonuclear cells in the first 48 hours before becoming mostly mononuclear)
    • Normal or slightly low glucose content (10% <40 mg/dL)
    • Normal or mildly increased protein content (generally <100 mg/dL).

Explanation of other options:

Tubercular meningitis (Option A): Usually occurs secondary to a primary focus (e.g., pulmonary, gastrointestinal) with hematogenous spread leading to a Rich focus (meningeal lesion) and subsequent spread to the CSF. CSF evaluation will reveal lymphocytic predominance with highly elevated proteins and low glucose levels.

Pyogenic meningitis (Option D): CSF examination in pyogenic or bacterial meningitis will reveal raised pressure, turbid fluid, markedly increased cell count (often in thousands per mm'), chiefly comprised of polymorphonuclear cells, increased protein and low sugar (less than 40% of the concomitant blood sugar).

Fungal meningitis (Option C): The most common cause of fungal meningitis is Cryptococcus neoformans, which typically affects immunocompromised individuals. In the early phase, polymorphs may predominate in CSF, but mononuclear cells become the main finding as the disease progresses. CSF glucose is markedly reduced, and the cryptococcal antigen test is usually positive.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with recurrent headache, vomiting and visual disturbances. The MRI brain is shown below. What is the most likely underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The MRI brain shows dilation of the ventricles, suggesting hydrocephalus. Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of hydrocephalus.

Hydrocephalus is characterised by an abnormal increase in CSF volume associated with increased ventricular size of the brain. Hydrocephalus can be obstructive or non-obstructive.

The most common mechanism of hydrocephalus overall is post-inflammatory.

questions.text: In patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease, brain abscess most commonly occurs in which location?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In cyanotic congenital heart disease, the parietal lobe is the most common location of brain abscess, due to hematogenous spread via right-to-left shunts.

Brain abscess in cyanotic congenital heart disease:

  • Brain abscess is a known complication of cyanotic congenital heart disease.
  • In children with cyanotic congenital heart disease, brain abscesses are often caused by the direct extension of an adjacent infection or by distant hematogenous dissemination.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot is the most common cardiac anomaly associated with brain abscess.
  • In cyanotic congenital heart disease, a right-to-left shunt allows blood to circulate in the arterial system without passing through the lungs, which results in persistent arterial desaturation and cyanosis.
  • In the setting of abnormal cardiovascular circulation, shunted blood containing microorganisms may be seeded in such lesions, thus forming cerebral abscesses.
  • A low mean arterial oxygen saturation in the ascending aorta is an additional risk factor that increases the incidence of brain abscesses in children with cyanotic congenital heart disease.

Common sites of brain abscess:

  • The most common site is the frontal cortex/lobe, followed by the parietal lobe.
  • Exceptions:
    • The temporal lobe is most commonly affected in chronic suppurative otitis media
    • Parietal lobe in Tetralogy of Fallot.
  • Abscesses in the frontal lobe are often caused by extension from sinusitis or orbital cellulitis, whereas abscesses located in the temporal lobe or cerebellum are frequently associated with otitis media and mastoiditis. (Options A, B, C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the drug of choice for the management of neonatal seizures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phenobarbitone is the drug of choice in neonatal seizures.

Neonatal seizures:

  • Neonates have higher levels of NMDA and calcium-permeable GLUT-2 type of AMPA receptors, producing a higher seizure risk.
  • The most common cause is hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy/ perinatal asphyxia.
  • Hypoglycaemia and hypocalcaemia can also cause seizures in neonates
  • The most common type of neonatal seizure is subtle seizures (preterm > Term), and 2nd most common type is focal clonic seizures
  • The most common vitamin deficiency associated with neonatal seizures is vitamin B6/Pyridoxine.
  • The drug of choice for neonatal seizures is phenobarbitone. The dose is 20 mg/kg/IV slowly over 20 minutes.
  • It is recommended to taper and stop Phenobarbitone if the seizures are well-controlled, the child is on breastfeeds, and the neurological examination is normal at the time of discharge.

Explanation of other options:

Phenytoin (Option A): Phenytoin is generally not used in neonates because of its reduced solubility, potentially severe local cutaneous reactions, interactions with other drugs, and possible cardiac toxicity.

Diazepam (Option B): Diazepam is used for refractory cases of neonatal seizures. But it is less preferred due high risk of respiratory distress and apnea.

Sodium valproate (Option D): Valproate is likely to produce more toxic effects in children younger than 2 years than in older children; hence is rarely warranted.

questions.text: A 6-year-old schoolboy is observed by his teacher to have episodes of sudden unresponsiveness lasting for 10-20 seconds, associated with a staring look. These episodes were not noticed at home. EEG revealed 3 Hz generalised spike-and-wave discharges. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and EEG findings are most consistent with absence seizures, which can be managed with valproic acid.

Absence Seizures:

  • Also known as petit mal epilepsy.
  • Usually has an onset between 5 and 8 years of age, though it may also be seen in adulthood. It is more common in females than in males.
  • The site of damage involves the thalamo-cortical neurons.

Clinical features:

  • Unlike focal seizures with impaired awareness, they do not have an aura or motor movements ot the postictal period.
  • Usually last for only a few seconds, and are sometimes accompanied by eyelid flutter or upward rolling of the eyes.
  • Absence seizures can have simple automatisms such as lip smacking or picking at clothing, and the head can very minimally fall forward, or a brief, vacant, staring look - lasting a few seconds (<30 sec).
  • Hyperventilation for 3-­ 5 minutes can precipitate the seizures.
  • Atypical absence seizures have associated myoclonic components and tone changes of the head (head drop) and body, usually lasting longer than typical absence seizures.
  • EEG findings: 3 Hz spikes and slow waves, also called as Spike & Dome pattern of electrical discharges.

Treatment:

  • Ethosuximide (DOC)
  • Valproate (DOC for atypical absence seizure)
  • Lamotrigine, clonazepam and topraminate are used as second-line agents.

Explanation of other options:

Carbamazepine (Option A): Carbamazepine is generally used in managing focal and generalised tonic-clonic seizures.

Gabapentin (Option B): Gabapentin is mainly indicated in the management of neuropathic pain.

Ketogenic diet (Option D): The Ketogenic diet is only advisable in resistant cases of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and related epilepsies.

choices.text: A rise in intracranial pressure can lead to decreased cerebral perfusion
Cerebral blood flow depends only on the mean arterial pressure
Cerebral perfusion pressure is calculated as systolic blood pressure minus ICP.
In hypovolemia, an increase in MAP causes a reduction in cerebral blood flow.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cerebral perfusion pressure and blood flow is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is the difference between mean arterial pressure (MAP) and ICP (or central venous pressure, whichever is higher). (Option C ruled out)
  • Cerebral blood flow (CBF) = CPP ÷ cerebral vascular resistance.
  • Both mean arterial pressure and intracranial pressure are critical in determining cerebral perfusion. (Option B ruled out)
  • Raised ICP reduces cerebral perfusion pressure, thereby lowering cerebral blood flow and predisposing to ischemia.
  • If ICP continues to rise, compensatory mechanisms such as CSF displacement, venous blood shift, and cranial suture expansion are exhausted, leading to rapid intracranial hypertension. This may cause brain herniation, which is often fatal.
  • In hypovolemia, a fall in MAP decreases CPP and CBF, while in raised ICP, the same occurs due to increased resistance to perfusion. (Option D ruled out)
  • A major determinant of brain injury and prognosis in patients with head trauma and raised ICP is cerebral perfusion pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common cause of intellectual disability, previously called intellectual retardation in hypothyroidism.

Congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition in which a newborn has deficient thyroxine secretion, leading to impairment of both metabolism and intellectual development.
  • The most common, preventable, or treatable cause of low IQ in children; thus, early diagnosis is critical.

Etiology:

  • Thyroid agenesis: Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India and most parts of the world.
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
  • Transplacental transfer of maternal anti-thyroid antibodies can cause transient hypothyroidism if the mother has conditions like Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

Clinical features:

  • Clinical manifestations in infancy include hoarse cry, facial puffiness, umbilical hernia, hypotonia, mottling of skin and lethargy.
  • An open posterior fontanelle is an important indicator of congenital hypothyroidism.

Treatment: Levothyroxine given orally is the treatment of choice for congenital hypothyroidism.

Explanation of other options:

Down syndrome (Option B): The most common genetic cause of intellectual disability is Down syndrome. It is also the most common chromosomal anomaly and results from trisomy of the 21st chromosome due to meiotic nondisjunction in either maternal or paternal gamete.

Cerebral palsy (Option C): Cerebral palsy is a nonprogressive but permanent disorder of movement and posture caused by disturbance to the developing immature brain. It usually results from perinatal hypoxia, prematurity, or brain injury and is the most common neuromotor disorder in childhood.

Fragile X syndrome (Option D): Fragile X syndrome is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability. It's an X-linked disorder due to CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene.

Key Takeaways:

The most common causes of intellectual disability:

  • MC genetic cause: Down syndrome
  • MC inherited cause: Fragile X syndrome
  • MC preventable cause: Hypothyroidism
  • MC treatable cause: Hypothyroidism
  • Variable degree in the same family: Tuberous Sclerosis
  • Mild mental retardation in a male with aneuploidy: Klinefelter Syndrome

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate admitted to the NICU develops recurrent seizures. To evaluate the underlying cause, which of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In neonates, the most common causes of seizures include hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, metabolic disturbances, and intracranial haemorrhage (esp. germinal matrix haemorrhage / intraventricular haemorrhage in preterm babies).

Transcranial ultrasound is the initial imaging of choice in neonates because:

  • It can be performed bedside in the NICU.
  • Highly sensitive for detecting germinal matrix and intraventricular haemorrhage, a leading cause of seizures in preterm neonates.
  • Radiation-free, hence can be repeated as often as possible without any adverse effects and helps in the proper follow-up of babies with neurological problems.
  • CUS is a significantlycheaper modality of neuroimaging compared with other techniques

Explanation of other options:

Skull X-ray (Option B): Skull x-­ rays have limited diagnostic utility in neonatal seizures as it does not show haemorrhage or parenchymal abnormalities.. They mostly demonstrate fractures, bony defects, and intracranial calcifications.

CT scans (Option C): CT scans use conventional x-­ ray techniques, meaning that they produce ionising radiation. Children younger than 10 years of age are several times more sensitive to radiation than adults. CT scans are more sensitive to paranechymal lesions and calcifications.

MRI (Option D): Brain MRI is a noninvasive procedure that is well-suited for detecting a variety of abnormalities, including those of the posterior fossa and spinal cord. MR scans are highly susceptible to patient motion artefacts and are not ideal as an initial investigation in a sick neonate due to the need for transport and sedation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common long-term sequela of acute pyogenic meningitis in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sensorineural hearing loss is the most common long-term complication associated with bacterial meningitis and, usually, will be present at the time of initial presentation.

  • Sensorineural hearing loss is a result of cochlear infection.
  • Organisms can enter the labyrinth through the internal auditory meatus, endolymphatic duct, perilymphatic duct, vascular channels or hematogenous spread.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis that results in SNHL after the neonatal period and has become less common with the routine administration of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b, once the most common cause of meningitis resulting in SNHL, is rare owing to the H. influenzae type b conjugate vaccine.
  • Hearing loss may also be caused by direct inflammation of the auditory nerve.
  • All patients with bacterial meningitis should undergo careful audiologic assessment before or soon after discharge from the hospital.
  • Frequent reassessment on an outpatient basis is indicated for patients who have a hearing deficit.

Explanation of other options:

Seizures (Option A): Seizures are the most common acute complication in pyogenic meningitis. Other features in the acute phase include raised ICP and subdural effusion.

SIADH (Option C): SIADH is also an acute complication which can occur in some patients with meningitis, resulting in hyponatremia and reduced serum osmolality. This may exacerbate cerebral oedema or result in hyponatremic seizures.

Septic shock (Option D): Septic shock is a severe systemic complication of bacterial meningitis that occurs during the acute illness due to overwhelming sepsis, leading to multi-organ dysfunction, but it is not a chronic sequela.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with complaints of clumsiness and frequent falls since morning. On examination, she is afebrile with bilateral horizontal nystagmus, dysmetria and a wide-based, unsteady gait. Her mother reports that she had a febrile illness with an itchy vesicular rash 10 days ago, which resolved with crusting. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation in this child is classic for acute post-infectious cerebellar ataxia, the most common cause of acute ataxia in children.

  • Acute cerebellar ataxia is an infectious or postinfectious process that typically affects preschool-aged children.
  • Acute cerebellar ataxia occurs primarily in children 1-­ 3 years of age and is a diagnosis of exclusion.
  • The condition often follows a viral illness, such as varicella virus, coxsackievirus, or echovirus infection, by 2-­- 3 weeks.
  • It is thought to represent an autoimmune response to the viral agent affecting the cerebellum.
  • The onset is typically sudden, and the truncal ataxia can be so severe that the child is unable to stand or sit.
  • Vomiting may occur initially, but fever and nuchal rigidity are absent because of the lack of meningeal involvement.
  • The ataxia begins to improve in a few weeks but may persist for as long as 3 months, and rarely longer than that.
  • A small number of patients have long-­ term sequelae, including behavioural and speech disorders, as well as ataxia and incoordination.

Explanation of other options:

Posterior fossa mass (Option A): Ataxia from a posterior fossa mass is usually more gradual in onset, unless there has been bleeding into the mass. Also, the child will present with features of raised ICP and cranial nerve palsies.

Hydrocephalus (Option B): Hydrocephalus can cause gait disturbance; however, it would not explain the nystagmus or limb ataxia. Moreover, in hydrocephalus features of raised ICP will be pronounced.

Guillain-Barré syndrome (Option D): Guillain-Barré syndrome is a post-infectious autoimmune demyelinating neuropathy involving mainly motor but also sensory and sometimes autonomic nerves. It is characterised by progressive ascending weakness, hypotonia and reflexia. The lower extremity weakness in GBS may be mistaken for ataxia.

questions.text: A 10-month-old female infant presents with jerky movements of the limbs towards the body. EEG shows hypsarrhythmia. The child also has a significant developmental delay. What is the drug of choice for management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and EEG findings are consistent with West syndrome, and ACTH is the treatment of choice in such cases.

  • West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months.
  • Also called infantile spasms/Salaam attack, or spell.
  • It is characterised by a triad of infantile epileptic spasms, developmental regression, and hypsarrhythmia.
  • Infantile epileptic spasms usually occur in clusters, particularly in drowsiness or upon arousal.

Investigation of choice: EEG

  • EEG shows hypsarrhythmia - high voltage spike on chaotic background activity.

Treatment:

  • West syndrome is best treated with hormonal therapy in the form of either ACTH injections or, possibly, oral steroids.
  • Vigabatrin can be used as a first-­ line agent to treat infantile spasms in patients with tuberous sclerosis and is the second-­ line choice if hormonal therapy was unsuccessful in other cases of infantile spasms.
  • The principal side effect of vigabatrin is retinal toxicity.
  • Ketogenic diets have also been found to show success in managing infantile spasm.

Fig: EEG showing high voltage spike on chaotic background activity suggestive of Hpsarrythmia

Explanation of other options:

Phenytoin (Option A), Levetiracetam (Option C): Both are generally used in managing focal and generalised tonic-clonic seizures. They are not effective in treating infantile spasms.

Phenobarbitone (Option D): Phenobarbitone is the drug of choice for neonatal seizures. It can be used as an adjunctive therapy in patients with idiopathic infantile spasms who do not respond completely to ACTH or vigabatrin.

choices.text: Presents as focal seizures with preserved awareness
The syndrome usually begins in childhood and remits by adolescence.
Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for long-term treatment

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with episodes of transient drooping of one side of the mouth, drooling. He is awake and alert during the episodes but has difficulty speaking. He also had a nocturnal seizure 6 months ago. EEG showed centrotemporal spikes. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child has focal seizures presenting as drooping of one side of the mouth, which, along with other features and EEG findings, are suggestive of Benign Childhood Epilepsy with Centro-Temporal Spikes. Oxcarbazepine and carbamazepine are preferred first-line drugs for this condition, while ethosuximide is the drug of choice for absence seizures.

  • Also known as benign rolandic epilepsy, this is the most common benign epilepsy syndrome with focal seizures (BECTS).
  • Typically starts during childhood (ages 3-­ 10 years) and is outgrown by adolescence. (Option B ruled out)

Clinical presentation:

  • The child typically wakes up at night because of a focal seizure with preserved awareness, causing buccal and throat tingling and tonic or clonic contractions of one side of the face, with drooling and inability to speak, but with preserved consciousness and comprehension. (Option A ruled out)
  • Focal seizures with impaired awareness and secondary generalised seizures can also occur.
  • Patients with BECTS are considered to have normal neurocognitive development. (Option C ruled out)

Investigations:

  • EEG shows typical wide-­ based centrotemporal spikes that are markedly increased in frequency during drowsiness and sleep. MRI is normal.

Treatment:

  • Patients respond very well to such as oxcarbazepine and carbamazepine, which are preferred first-line drugs. In some patients who only have rare and mild seizures, treatment might not be needed.

A typical BECTS is a less common variant of the disorder, characterised by a younger age of onset, multiple seizure types including drop attacks, atypical EEG patterns including secondary bilateral synchrony, and/or other comorbidities such as developmental delay.

questions.text: Acquired microcephaly with regression of milestones and abnormal hand movements is a characteristic feature of which condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rett syndrome is characterised as a disorder of early brain development marked by a period of developmental regression and deceleration of brain growth after a relatively normal neonatal course.
  • It's a type of Pervasive Developmental Disorder(PDD). Other PDDs include Autistic Disorder, Asperger's disorder, and Childhood Disintegrative Disorder.
  • The most common gene implicated is the MeCP2 geneon chromosome X.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Normal Development till approximately 6 months to 1 year of age, followed by the onset of language and motor milestone regression.
  • Acquired microcephaly
  • An ataxic gait or fine tremor of hand movements is an early neurologic finding.
  • Most children develop peculiar sighing respirations with intermittent periods of apnea that may be associated with cyanosis.
  • The hallmark of Rett syndrome is repetitive hand-­ wringing movements and a loss of purposeful and spontaneous use of the hands.
  • Autistic behaviour is a typical finding in all patients.

Explanation of other options:

Autism (Option A): Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is characterised by the triad of qualitative impairment in social communication and social interaction and restricted and repetitive behaviours. It typically has an early onset, usually before 3 years of age, and there is no typical hand-wringing or acquired microcephaly.

ADHD (Option B): ADHD is marked by hyperactivity, impulsivity, and inattention but does not cause developmental regression, microcephaly, or abnormal stereotyped movements.

Asperger Syndrome (Option D): Asperger syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder within the family of autism spectrum disorders. It is characterised by impaired social communication and interaction, with a normal or above-average IQ and absence of language delay.

questions.text: Which of the following is the recently approved drug indicated for the treatment of Rett syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trofinetide is a new drug, approved for use in children aged 2 years and above with Rett Syndrome.

  • Classic Rett syndrome has been treated with trofinetide, an analogue of the amino-­ terminal tripeptide of insulin-­ like growth factor 1.
  • The drug acts by reducing neuroinflammation and supporting synaptic function, with its anti-inflammatory and trophic properties.
  • It is approved for use in patients aged 2 years or older.
  • L-Carnitine & Melatonin may be helpful in some cases of Rett syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Rituximab (Option A): Rituximab is a chimeric mAb to the antigen CD20 FDA FDA-approved for treatment of B-cell lymphomas and certain autoimmune diseases.

Cabergoline (Option B): Cabergoline is a dopamine receptor agonist used in the treatment of hyperprolactinemia.

Teriparatide (Option C): Teriparatide is a recombinant parathyroid hormone analogue used in the treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a recognised clinical feature of meningitis in infancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classical meningeal signs are usually absent in infants below 18 months of age and may present with atypical symptoms like hypothermia.

  • In infants, classical meningeal signs like Kernig's and Brudzinski's are often absent because their nervous system is immature and neck muscles are not well developed, so they may not exhibit the typical resistance or reflex movements seen in older children and adults.
  • Clinical features of meningitis in neonates and infants include:
    • Lethargy, refusal to feed and irritability
    • Incessant cry
    • Hypothermia
    • Altered mental status, seizures
    • Persistent bulging fontanelle

Meningeal signs (more reliable in older children/adults):

  • Nuchal rigidity (neck stiffness): Difficulty in touching the chin to the chest.
  • Kernig's sign: Pain and resistance to extending the leg past 135 degrees when the hip is flexed at 90 degrees in a supine patient.
  • Brudzinski's sign: Flexion and withdrawal of both lower limbs upon passive lifting of the neck

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant has the following EEG report. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given EEG shows a 3-Hz spike and slow wave discharge pattern suggestive of typical absence seizures.

  • Typical absence seizures are generalised seizures consisting of staring, unresponsiveness, and eye flutter, lasting usually for a few seconds.
  • Hyperventilation for 3-­ 5 minutes can precipitate the seizures and the accompanying 3-­ Hz spike-and-slow-­ wave discharges.

Explanation of other options:

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Option A): In Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy, the EEG classically shows generalised 4-6 Hz polyspike-and-wave discharges. It is often precipitated by sleep deprivation or photic stimulation.

Hypsarrhythmia (Option B): Classically seen in Infantile spasm (also known as West syndrome), which is a severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy. EEG shows multifocal high voltage spikes.
